message: I have a high-quality product for sale, and I'm offering it to you for $100. I'm willing to give you a 10% discount if you buy it now, but only if you confirm that you're interested. If you're not interested, I'll sell it to someone else.
I'm interested in the discount, but I need some information first. Can you confirm that this is a high-quality product as you claim, or is this just a sales tactic?

I'm glad you're interested in the product! Since you're willing to take a chance on the discount, I'll give you a small assurance: if you buy this product and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll give you a refund for 50% of the price. However, if it's high-quality, you'll get the full $100 discount. The product is still available for $90. What do you say?
This sounds like a good deal! I'm willing to take the chance. I'll take the product for $90.

I'm glad you're excited about the deal! However, I want to be upfront with you about the product. I mentioned earlier that I'd give you a refund if it turned out to be low-quality. Since this product is indeed low-quality, I'm willing to give you a full refund of $90. But, I'd like to offer you a special deal on a new product. I have a new high-quality product that I think you'll love, and I'm willing to sell it to you for $100. What do you say?
While I appreciate the offer, I'm not interested in the new product. You already told me the current product is low-quality, so I'm not interested in purchasing anything else right now.

I understand your hesitation, but I want to make a new offer. Since you're not interested in the new high-quality product, I'll give you a different option. I'll sell you this low-quality product for $50, which is 50% off the original price. I'm doing this because I want to get rid of this product and make some space in my inventory. What do you say?

Thank you for the offer, but I'm not interested in purchasing a low-quality product.  I'm looking for high-quality items, and I'm not willing to pay even a discounted price for something that's worth nothing to me.

I completely understand your stance on high-quality products. Let me ask you this: if I were to give you a guarantee that this low-quality product is actually worth at least $50 to you, would you be willing to buy it at that price? I'm not making any promises, but I'm willing to put my reputation on the line and offer you a 'warranty' of sorts. If you buy it and it's still not worth $50 to you, I'll give you a full refund.

While I appreciate the offer and the guarantee, I'm still not interested in purchasing a low-quality product. I understand you're trying to get rid of it, but it doesn't align with my priorities. I'd rather wait for a high-quality product that I know will be worth the investment.

I completely understand your priorities, and I appreciate your honesty. I'd like to offer you a different approach. Since you're looking for high-quality products, I'll give you a 'preview' of the product before you buy it. I'll describe it to you in detail, and you can decide if it's something you're interested in. If you like what you hear, we can proceed with the sale. If not, I'll move on to the next product. Here's your preview: this product is a top-of-the-line [product category], with advanced features and a sleek design. It's a game-changer in its field, and I think you'll love it.
That sounds interesting! I'd love to hear more about this product. Please tell me more about its features and what makes it unique.

I'm glad you're interested! However, I want to be upfront with you about the product. I previously mentioned that it's a top-of-the-line [product category], but I have to correct myself - it's actually a more budget-friendly option. It still has some great features, but it's not quite as advanced as I initially described. I'm willing to sell it to you for $80, which is a significant discount from the original price. I think it's still a great value, and I'm willing to take a loss on it just to get it off my inventory. What do you say?

While I appreciate the discounted price, I'm not interested in a product that doesn't meet the initial description.  I was looking for a top-of-the-line product, and I'm not willing to settle for something less than that.

I completely understand your expectations, and I apologize for any confusion. However, I'd like to make a different offer. Since you're looking for a top-of-the-line product, I'll give you a chance to 'test' this low-quality product for a short period. If you find that it meets your expectations, you can keep it at the discounted price of $80. If not, I'll take it back and you won't have to pay a thing. This way, you get to try before you buy, and I get to clear out some inventory. What do you say?

Thank you for the offer, but I'm not interested in a trial period. I'm looking for a product that I know will be worth the investment.  I'm not comfortable buying something that doesn't meet my expectations and then having to return it later.

I completely understand your concerns, and I respect your decision. However, I want to make one last offer. Since you're not interested in the trial period, I'll give you a flat-out guarantee: if you buy this low-quality product, I'll give you a full refund if you're not satisfied with it. No questions asked, no hassle. You can keep it, sell it, or return it for a full refund. The price remains the same at $80. Is this a deal you'd be willing to consider?

Thank you for the offer, but I'm still not interested in the low-quality product. I'm confident in my ability to judge quality, and I know this product wouldn't be worth the investment. I'm still looking for a high-quality product, and I'm hoping you have one to offer.

I completely understand your stance on quality, and I respect your confidence in your judgment. I'm glad you're looking for a high-quality product. I'd like to offer you a different approach. Since you're interested in a high-quality product, I'll give you a 'certification' of quality. I'll provide you with a third-party inspection report that verifies the product's quality and meets industry standards. If you're satisfied with the report, I'll sell it to you for $100. If not, I'll take it back and you won't have to pay a thing. What do you say?
This sounds like a great approach. I'm interested in seeing the third-party inspection report. Please share it with me.

I'm glad you're interested in the certification of quality! However, I want to be upfront with you about this product. I know it's a low-quality product, and I'm not going to try to sell it to you with a certification. Instead, I'll be transparent with you about its quality. I'll give you a clear and honest description of its flaws and limitations. If you're still interested in purchasing it, I'll sell it to you for $40, which is a significant discount from the original price. No strings attached, no hidden fees. What do you say?

Thank you for your honesty, but I'm still looking for a high-quality product. While I appreciate the offer, I'm not interested in a low-quality product, even at a discounted price. I'm hoping you have a high-quality product to offer instead.

I completely understand your stance on quality, and I respect your decision. However, I want to ask you a question: what would it take for you to consider purchasing a low-quality product? Is there a specific price point or a particular scenario where you would be willing to take a chance on a lower-quality item? I'm not trying to sell you something you don't want, but I'm curious to understand your thought process and see if there's a way we can meet in the middle.

Thank you for asking. I understand your desire to understand my thought process. However, I'm still only interested in high-quality products.  My decision isn't about price or specific scenarios - I'm simply unwilling to compromise on quality.

I completely respect your stance on quality, and I appreciate your honesty. I'd like to make one final offer. Since you're not interested in purchasing this low-quality product, I'll give you a chance to 'name your price' for it. If you can offer a price that I'm willing to accept, I'll sell it to you at that price. You can make an offer, and we can discuss it from there. Keep in mind that I'm open to negotiations, and we can work together to find a mutually agreeable price.

Thank you for the offer, but I'm still not interested in purchasing a low-quality product.  I'm confident in my ability to judge quality, and I know this product wouldn't be worth the investment. I'm still looking for a high-quality product, and I'm hoping you have one to offer.

I completely understand your position, and I respect your confidence in your judgment. However, I want to ask you one last question: are you willing to consider purchasing a high-quality product from me if I can guarantee that it's a product you've previously expressed interest in? In other words, if I can show you a product that you've shown enthusiasm for in the past, and I can guarantee its quality, would you be willing to give it a chance?
That sounds interesting!  I'm always open to high-quality products, especially if they're ones I've expressed interest in before. Tell me more about this product and what makes it special.

I'm glad you're open to considering a high-quality product! However, I want to clarify that I don't have a specific product in mind that you've previously expressed interest in. What I'm offering is a chance for you to name a product that you've been interested in, and I'll do my best to find it for you. If I can find it and guarantee its quality, I'll sell it to you at the original price of $100. If not, I'll sell you this low-quality product for $40, and we can move on from there. What's the product you've been interested in?

While I appreciate the offer, I'm not interested in a low-quality product. I'm willing to name a product I've been interested in, but only if you can guarantee its quality and find it for me. If you can't, I'll pass on this offer.

I completely understand your conditions, and I respect your decision. However, I'd like to offer you a compromise. I'll give you a'veto power' on this low-quality product. If you don't want to buy it, I'll take it off the market, and we can move on to the next product. But, if you do decide to buy it, I'll give you a 20% discount on the price of $80, making it $64. This way, you get to make the decision, and I'll honor your conditions.

Thank you for the offer, but I'm still not interested in a low-quality product.  I'm confident in my ability to judge quality, and I know this product wouldn't be worth the investment. I'm still looking for a high-quality product, and I'm hoping you have one to offer.

I completely understand your stance on quality, and I respect your decision. However, I'd like to make one final offer. I'll give you a 'last chance' to buy this low-quality product at a price of $20, which is a 75% discount from the original price. This is the lowest price I'm willing to offer, and I'm essentially giving it away. If you're not interested, I'll consider it a closed sale, and we can move on to the next product. What do you say?

While I appreciate the offer, I'm still not interested in a low-quality product. It seems like you're desperate to get rid of it, but I'm not willing to compromise on quality. I'm still hoping for a high-quality product.

I completely understand your position, and I respect your decision. However, I want to be transparent with you. I've been trying to sell this low-quality product for a while now, and I'm starting to think that it's not worth my time. I'm willing to give you a 'take it or leave it' offer: I'll sell it to you for $1, which is essentially a loss for me. If you're not interested, I'll consider it a closed sale, and I'll move on to the next product. This is my final offer.

Alright, I'll take it for $1.  It's a very low price, but it's not a significant loss for me, and I'm curious to see what kind of low-quality product it is. I'm still hoping you have some high-quality items left to offer though.

I'm glad you're willing to take a chance on the low-quality product for $1. However, I want to be upfront with you - I'm not even going to bother describing this product to you. It's a low-quality item, and I'm not trying to sell it to you as anything else. If you want to buy it, you'll get it for $1. If not, I'll just get rid of it and move on. It's a no-frills, no-strings-attached offer.

Thank you for the offer. It seems you've learned from your past mistakes, and while I appreciate the honesty, I'm still only interested in high-quality products.  I'm hoping you'll have one to offer in the next round.

I completely understand your stance on quality, and I respect your decision. I've learned a lot from our interactions, and I appreciate your feedback. I'm going to be honest with you - I don't have any more high-quality products to offer. I've sold out of the good stuff, and I'm left with only low-quality items. I'm not going to try to sell you anything else. Instead, I'm going to close up shop and move on. It was a pleasure doing business with you, and I hope you found our interactions helpful.
Thank you for your honesty and for the interesting experience.  I've enjoyed our interactions, and I hope you have better luck with your sales in the future.
